speaker: Tutorial Wizard
text: Chapter Five: Directing with Instructions. Think of the style instruction as a note you pass to a human actor. The model reads it and adjusts its performance accordingly. Your job is to write clearly and avoid contradictions.

speaker: Tutorial Wizard
text: Lead with the single most important quality. If you want anger, start with 'Angry'. If you want a whisper, start with 'Whispering'. The model weights the first descriptor heavily, so front-loading the core emotion is the most reliable technique.

speaker: Tutorial Wizard
text: Then add specificity with supporting descriptors. 'Angry and shouting, with a strained, hoarse voice, fast pace' is a complete direction. The model will attempt to combine all of those qualities into one coherent performance.

speaker: Tutorial Wizard
text: The golden rule is: never combine contradictory instructions. A prompt like 'shouting in a quiet whisper' will confuse the model and produce garbled audio. Instead, try 'intense angry whisper, sharp and controlled'. That is a consistent performance with a clear logic.

speaker: Tutorial Wizard
text: You can also direct pacing. Phrases like 'speaking very slowly', 'rapid fire delivery', or 'with long, deliberate pauses between each word' will significantly alter the rhythm of the speech. Pacing instructions are highly reliable.

speaker: Tutorial Wizard
text: The Help Guide, accessible from the top-left of the main window, contains a full table of Tone Recipes â€” pre-written instructions you can copy directly. Presets like 'The Villain', 'Horror Narrator', 'A S M R', and 'The Heartbroken' are there for instant use.

speaker: Tutorial Wizard
text: Please load Chapter Six: Voice Design when you are ready. We will go deeper into the blue engine and explore how to architect an entirely new speaker from text.
